awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Benchtop NMR Instrument with Pulsed Field Gradient and Autosampler for Research and Research Training
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation, Chemistry Research Instrumentation, Chemistry of Life Processes and Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms B programs.  California State University at Monterey Bay is acquiring a 43 MHz benchtop nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectrometer that has the capabilities to perform both routine analysis and more complex experiments and helps elucidate molecular structures of chemical compounds.  The instrument supports the research of Professor John Goeltz and colleagues Corin Slown and Amy Danowitz at California State University at Monterey Bay.  This spectrometer allows research in a variety of fields such as development of battery materials, exploring quorum sensing pathways in interactions with small molecules, and carrying out research training in protein-ligand binding events.  In general, NMR spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists for the elucidation of the structures of molecules. It is used to identify unknown substances, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the dynamics of interactions between molecules in solution or in the solid state.  Access to state-of-the-art NMR spectrometers is essential to chemists who are carrying out frontier research.  This instrument is an integral part of teaching as well as research and research training of undergraduate students in the sciences.

The award of the NMR spectrometer is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels.  It will be especially impactful in providing critical hands-on research experience to students from underrepresented groups, first generation college students and female students at this Hispanic Serving Institution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) is a powerful tool to analyze and identify molecular structures at an atomic level. This technology provides students with analytical skills widely used in fields like chemistry, biochemistry, and materials science. Experience using an NMR helps students to gain a deep understanding of molecular properties, conduct research, and prepare them for careers in various scientific fields where NMR analysis is widely used. The use of NMR develops critical thinking skills through the interpretation of complex NMR spectra. NMR is a primary method for determining the detailed structure of molecules, including the arrangement of atoms and functional groups, which is vital for understanding chemical reactions and designing new compounds. Interpreting NMR spectra requires careful analysis of complex data, including chemical shifts, coupling constants, and peak integrations, which enhances critical thinking skills. An additional benefit for students is that unlike other analytical techniques, NMR allows for non-destructive analysis of samples. NMR is used across various disciplines, including pharmaceuticals, food science, polymer science, medicine (through MRI), and agriculture. 

 

These technical capabilities enable chemical research with undergraduates at a Hispanic Serving Institution.  Without an NMR, advancement of our research in physical and chemical sciences is severely limited. Recent advances in both hardware and software have greatly improved spectral resolution. Students engaged in a Course-Based Undergraduate Research Experience (CURE) in an organic chemistry lab course are able to make a molecule, characterize it, and purify it in a single class period.  As the instrument does not require deuterated solvents, the synthesis and characterization of oils undertaken in the CURE reduces the cost associated with labs. Multidimensional spectroscopy such as COSY, ROESY and, with a pulsed field gradient, DOSY improves the characterization suite with regard to small molecules. Having an NMR instrument removes a major limitation on the growth of research in chemistry and molecular biology.  As the presence of chemistry at our HSI grows, this development could enable a chemistry major with graduates that are competitive on the job and grad school markets.  Enhancing research training at an HSI like CSUMB (46% Latino/a, 60% female, 51% under-represented minority, 47% first generation to attend college, and 48% low income) leads to diversity in the workforce.

 

For example, electrochemistry is broad and interdisciplinary by nature and as such has become a powerful tool in science, technology, engineering, math, and medical (STEMM) fields ranging from energy storage to biotechnology. However, traditional undergraduate chemistry education does not offer students the opportunity to create direct connections between topics learned in a lecture course and applications beyond the examples depicted in textbooks. Work by Professor John Goeltz introduced students to aggregates in active battery electrolytes. Quorum-sensing modulators are chemical compounds that can interfere with the chemical signals that bacteria use to communicate with each other. These modulators can either inhibit or activate quorum sensing. Work by Professor Amy Danowitz introduced students to small molecule quorum-sensing modulators and anti-inflammatory binding. Professor Crystal Gonzalez-Samano and Professor Corin Slown cultivated the analytical skills of their students using NMR through Course-Based Undergraduate Research Experiences (CUREs), where students synthesized small molecules, purified, and analyzed their structures using NMR. Students also utilized the NMR in other CUREs in biochemistry and aqueous chemistry courses. NMR spectroscopic techniques help students characterize the interaction of small molecules with macromolecules such as proteins. Similarly, Professor Meagan Hynes and her students used the NMR in the context of agriculture soil management and research with her students about soil amendments.

 

Proficiency in NMR opens doors to research opportunities in academia and industry where NMR is used to study molecular interactions, reaction mechanisms, and develop new materials. Students have found positions at the intersection of chemistry and ecology using NMR spectroscopy to study the molecular structures and characteristics of environmental pollutants. Students have pursued graduate programs in pharmacology, which depend on NMR spectra for drug discovery and development. Students have been hired as food quality control scientists who apply NMR spectroscopy to analyze nutrients found in food products.

 

Students with this training are more competitive for jobs and for graduate school. For example, with these skills, students have been hired at local companies such as Monterey Bay Analytical Services. In addition, students have been accepted to graduate programs in chemistry and molecular biology. Over 1207 students have already been trained to use the NMR. Subsequent semesters will increase the number of students whose knowledge, technical skills, and critical thinking prepare them for the emerging workforce.
